itemDescription: British writer, original editor of Everyman's Library

wikipedia_page.main: Ernest Percival Rhys (; 17 July 1859 – 25 May 1946) was a Welsh-English writer, best known for his role as founding editor of the Everyman's Library series of affordable classics. He wrote essays, stories, poetry, novels and plays.

The Rhymers' Club was a group of London-based male poets, founded in 1890 by W. B. Yeats and Ernest Rhys. Originally not much more than a dining club, it produced anthologies of poetry in 1892 and 1894.The Oxford Companion to English Literature (2010) They met at the London pub ‘Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese’ in Fleet Street and in the 'Domino Room' of the Café Royal.Bernard Muddiman (1921) The Men of the Nineties, G.P. Putnam's Sons, New York

Along with the social element of the Rhymers' Club, they published two volumes of verse. The first, entitled The Book of the Rhymers' Club was published by Elkin Mathews in 1892. The Second Book of the Rhymers' Club appeared two years later in 1894, published by the recently merged Elkin Mathews and John Lane. They had print runs of 450 and 650 respectively. Those of the group appearing in these two volumes were: T.W. Rolleston, John Todhunter, W.B. Yeats, Richard Le Gallienne, Lionel Johnson, Arthur Cecil Hillier, Ernest Dowson, Victor Plarr, Ernest Radford, Arthur Symons, G.A. Greene, Edwin J. Ellis, and Ernest Rhys.

In A Sinking Island, Hugh Kenner wrote:  "Destiny beckoned J. M. Dent toward the kingdom of books, and without ever learning to spell he became an influential bookman.  He was small, lame, tight-fisted, and apt to weep under pressure, a performance that could disconcert authors and employees.  When his temper had risen like a flame he'd scream; the scream, one employee recalled, was what broke men's spirits.  His paroxysms were famous; a Swedish specialist thought of prescribing a pail of cold water for Dent to plunge his head into.  For editing the Library he paid Ernest Rhys three guineas a volume—what senior office-boys might earn in two weeks.  Dent's ungovernable passion was for bringing Books to the People.  He remembered when he'd longed to buy books he couldn't afford.  Yes, you could make the world better.  He even thought cheap books might prevent wars."New York Times Book Review, February 28, 1988.

Between 1878 and 1932, Tagore set foot in more than thirty countries on five continents. In 1912, he took a sheaf of his translated works to England, where they gained attention from missionary and Gandhi protégé Charles F. Andrews, Irish poet William Butler Yeats, Ezra Pound, Robert Bridges, Ernest Rhys, Thomas Sturge Moore, and others. Yeats wrote the preface to the English translation of Gitanjali; Andrews joined Tagore at Santiniketan. In November 1912 Tagore began touring the United States and the United Kingdom, staying in Butterton, Staffordshire with Andrews's clergymen friends. From May 1916 until April 1917, he lectured in Japan and the United States. He denounced nationalism. His essay "Nationalism in India" was scorned and praised; it was admired by Romain Rolland and other pacifists.
Frances Jenkins Olcott's 1942 anthology Good Stories For Great Holidays included a version of Charlotte S. Burne's "The King of the Cats" adapted by Ernest Rhys.
